block.p: Joseph I. Lieberman's personal financial statement -- which includes the investments of his wife, Hadassah -- shows a conservative list of investments, with the bulk of his net worth coming from mutual funds, a blind trust and real estate.

According to financial records for 1999, Mr. Lieberman earned $141,300 as a senator and received $45,000 in book royalties. He also received $10,735 in state pension money and income from being an estate trustee.

Joseph I. Lieberman's personal financial statement -- which includes the investments of his wife, Hadassah -- shows a conservative list of investments, with the bulk of his net worth coming from mutual funds, a blind trust and real estate.

According to financial records for 1999, Mr. Lieberman earned $141,300 as a senator and received $45,000 in book royalties. He also received $10,735 in state pension money and income from being an estate trustee.

Mr. Lieberman's investment portfolio is valued between $139,000 and $645,000, according to government statements that list all amounts as ranges and not as specific numbers. His largest investment is a blind trust valued at $100,000 to $250,000, and he has an individual retirement account consisting mainly of government securities valued at $9,000 to $135,000. In 1999, he listed capital gains of $30,000 to $122,000.

His investment portfolio also lists a Merrill Lynch account owned jointly with his wife, valued at $10,000 to $150,000. It consists of mutual funds and government securities. He also has bank savings accounts worth $20,000 to $110,000.

Mrs. Lieberman's portfolio consists of stocks and mutual funds valued at $18,000 to $90,000, and an individual retirement account valued at $63,000 to $405,000. Stocks held by Mrs. Lieberman include 800 shares of Pfizer, the pharmaceutical company, and 150 shares of Verizon, the telecommunications company, as well as shares in Viacom-CBS, Fox Entertainment and WorldCom. In the last year, the Liebermans sold 200 shares of Pfizer, 100 shares of CVS, a drug store chain, 500 shares of Occidental Petroleum and 50 shares of I.B.M.

The Liebermans own an investment condominium in New Haven valued at $52,500, according to tax records, and earned between $5,000 and $15,000 in rent from the condominium. They also have a house in the Georgetown section of Washington valued at $547,157, and a condominium in Connecticut valued at $150,486. The Georgetown house has a $285,000 mortgage, and the Liebermans have a mortgage of $50,000 to $100,000 on the second condominium.
